elements.content: Creating novel and practical materials to separate oil/water mixtures with high efficacy is in urgent demand. Herein, we demonstrate an amphipathic pentiptycene-based copper metal–organic framework (Cu-MOF; UPC-29) to satisfy this purpose. UPC-29 exhibits a efficient separation performance for mixtures of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water. Furthermore, materials under loose-packed and tight-pressed forms exhibit opposite hydrophilic–hydrophobic phenomena. This unique feature of UPC-29 provides a new avenue for the application of MOF materials.
elements.clean_text: Creating novel and practical materials to separate oil/water mixtures with high efficacy is in urgent demand. Herein, we demonstrate an amphipathic pentiptycene-based copper metal-organic framework (Cu-MOF; UPC-29) to satisfy this purpose. UPC-29 exhibits a efficient separation performance for mixtures of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water. Furthermore, materials under loose-packed and tight-pressed forms exhibit opposite hydrophilic-hydrophobic phenomena. This unique feature of UPC-29 provides a new avenue for the application of MOF materials.

elements.content: An amphipathic pentiptycene-based copper metal−organic framework (Cu-MOF), namely, UPC-29, has been constructed and characterized with a flexible carboxylate ligand. UPC-29 can realize the procedure of single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation by water induction and is applied to select oil/water separation of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water.
elements.clean_text: An amphipathic pentiptycene-based copper metal-organic framework (Cu-MOF), namely, UPC-29, has been constructed and characterized with a flexible carboxylate ligand. UPC-29 can realize the procedure of single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation by water induction and is applied to select oil/water separation of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water.

elements.content: Because of the ever-increasing oily wastewater and/or frequent oil-spill accidents, oil/water separation has attracted considerable worldwide attention. Thus, environmentally friendly, low-cost, and efficient materials based on the special wettability that can be used to separate the oil/water mixture has become the focus of research in recent years. Nowadays, various superwetting materials have been reported for potentially useful in oil/water separation, including modified meshes, carbon nanotubes, functionalized textiles, hybrid biomembranes, and nanofibrous mats, all of which are fabricated by designing (super)­hydrophobicity or (super)­oleophilicity surfaces. In general, the efficiency for oil/water separation of materials is highly dependent on the wettability, which is determined by the chemical composition and geometrical structure. Currently, some smart materials with surface functionalization have presented switchable wettability in response to external stimuli such as the pH value, solvent, light, temperature, and electric field. These smart materials have achieved surface wettability transitions, yet the approaches to dealing with materials are complex and time-consuming.
elements.clean_text: Because of the ever-increasing oily wastewater and/or frequent oil-spill accidents, oil/water separation has attracted considerable worldwide attention. Thus, environmentally friendly, low-cost, and efficient materials based on the special wettability that can be used to separate the oil/water mixture has become the focus of research in recent years. Nowadays, various superwetting materials have been reported for potentially useful in oil/water separation, including modified meshes, carbon nanotubes, functionalized textiles, hybrid biomembranes, and nanofibrous mats, all of which are fabricated by designing (super)hydrophobicity or (super)oleophilicity surfaces. In general, the efficiency for oil/water separation of materials is highly dependent on the wettability, which is determined by the chemical composition and geometrical structure. Currently, some smart materials with surface functionalization have presented switchable wettability in response to external stimuli such as the pH value, solvent, light, temperature, and electric field. These smart materials have achieved surface wettability transitions, yet the approaches to dealing with materials are complex and time-consuming.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with intricate structural architectures and topologies have attracted tremendous interest because of their significant applications. However, the poor stability of MOFs has being recognized as the main hindrance for their practical applications, especially the MOFs with binuclear CuII paddlewheel secondary building blocks (SBUs) in an aqueous environment. Typically, HKUST-1 possesses paddlewheel Cu2(COO)4 centers and is sensitive to moisture. Many efforts have been devoted to improving the stability of water-sensitive MOFs. For example, Jiang’s group has adopted a general strategy to modify hydrophobic poly­(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) on the surface of HKUST-1 to significantly enhance its moisture resistance. Sun’s group has used a pentiptycene-based carboxylate ligand to construct Cu-MOF (UPC-21), which exhibits high hydrophobicity to resist water. However, there are only a few water-resistant MOFs with CuII paddlewheel SBUs, and it is necessary to develop more to extend their applications.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with intricate structural architectures and topologies have attracted tremendous interest because of their significant applications. However, the poor stability of MOFs has being recognized as the main hindrance for their practical applications, especially the MOFs with binuclear CuII paddlewheel secondary building blocks (SBUs) in an aqueous environment. Typically, HKUST-1 possesses paddlewheel Cu2(COO)4 centers and is sensitive to moisture. Many efforts have been devoted to improving the stability of water-sensitive MOFs. For example, Jiang's group has adopted a general strategy to modify hydrophobic poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) on the surface of HKUST-1 to significantly enhance its moisture resistance. Sun's group has used a pentiptycene-based carboxylate ligand to construct Cu-MOF (UPC-21), which exhibits high hydrophobicity to resist water. However, there are only a few water-resistant MOFs with CuII paddlewheel SBUs, and it is necessary to develop more to extend their applications.

elements.content: Encouraged by the aforementioned works, we successfully obtained a 2D layer framework based on a flexible pentiptycene carboxylate ligand and binuclear CuII paddlewheel, named UPC-29 (CCDC 1569621). Strikingly, UPC-29 can change to UPC-29′ (CCDC 1843019) and UPC-29′′ (CCDC 1843020) by water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, indicating the hydrophilicity of Cu-SBU. In addition, the water contact angles were measured to be 178 ± 1° and 118 ± 1° in loose-packed and tight-pressed forms, respectively, suggesting the hydrophobicity of pentiptycene-based units. The practical oil/water separation experiments reveal that UPC-29 can be a good amphiphilic material for excellent oil/water separation.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by the aforementioned works, we successfully obtained a 2D layer framework based on a flexible pentiptycene carboxylate ligand and binuclear CuII paddlewheel, named UPC-29 (CCDC 1569621). Strikingly, UPC-29 can change to UPC-29' (CCDC 1843019) and UPC-29'' (CCDC 1843020) by water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, indicating the hydrophilicity of Cu-SBU. In addition, the water contact angles were measured to be 178 ± 1° and 118 ± 1° in loose-packed and tight-pressed forms, respectively, suggesting the hydrophobicity of pentiptycene-based units. The practical oil/water separation experiments reveal that UPC-29 can be a good amphiphilic material for excellent oil/water separation.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that UPC-29 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. As illustrated in a, the structure of UPC-29 is based on a dinuclear Cu paddlewheel and demonstrates a 2D packing sheet framework. Topologically, the 2D net can be simplified to a 4-connected sql network, with the dimensions of the smallest quadrangle being 22.93 × 23.11 Å. Furthermore, the neighboring 2D layers pile up in a −ABAB– pattern to configure a 3D supramolecular framework through the weak π···π interaction of multiaromatic pentiptycene-containing organic ligands (b).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that UPC-29 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. As illustrated in a, the structure of UPC-29 is based on a dinuclear Cu paddlewheel and demonstrates a 2D packing sheet framework. Topologically, the 2D net can be simplified to a 4-connected sql network, with the dimensions of the smallest quadrangle being 22.93 × 23.11 Å. Furthermore, the neighboring 2D layers pile up in a -ABAB- pattern to configure a 3D supramolecular framework through the weak π⋅⋅⋅π interaction of multiaromatic pentiptycene-containing organic ligands (b).

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of metal ions for UPC-29. (b) π···π stacking between two different nets from the c axis. (c) Dinuclear CuII paddlewheel clusters and a single-layer quadrangle net in UPC-29, UPC-29′, and UPC-29′′.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination mode of metal ions for UPC-29. (b) π⋅⋅⋅π stacking between two different nets from the c axis. (c) Dinuclear CuII paddlewheel clusters and a single-layer quadrangle net in UPC-29, UPC-29', and UPC-29''.

elements.content: When UPC-29 were immersed in water for 8 h, one of the two coordinated DMF molecules at the apical positions of the paddlewheel SBU was replaced by one H2O molecule, thus giving rise to UPC-29′. When the soaking time was extended overnight, the other coordinated DMF could be further replaced by a H2O molecule to generate UPC-29′′. This gradual conversion of UPC-29 to UPC-29′ and UPC-29′′ was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and powder X-ray diffraction (Figures S3–S8 and Tables S2–S5). Detailed structural analysis indicates that UPC-29, UPC-29′, and UPC-29′′ have similar structures. However, the dihedral angles and the dimensions of the smallest parallelogram are different (c). The significant differences for UPC-29, UPC-29′, and UPC-29′′ are attributed to the flexibility of L1 2–. The gradual replacement of the coordinated DMF molecules by H2O molecules indicates the hydrophilicity of the paddlewheel SBUs.
elements.clean_text: When UPC-29 were immersed in water for 8 h, one of the two coordinated DMF molecules at the apical positions of the paddlewheel SBU was replaced by one H2O molecule, thus giving rise to UPC-29'. When the soaking time was extended overnight, the other coordinated DMF could be further replaced by a H2O molecule to generate UPC-29''. This gradual conversion of UPC-29 to UPC-29' and UPC-29'' was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and powder X-ray diffraction (Figures S3-S8 and Tables S2-S5). Detailed structural analysis indicates that UPC-29, UPC-29', and UPC-29'' have similar structures. However, the dihedral angles and the dimensions of the smallest parallelogram are different (c). The significant differences for UPC-29, UPC-29', and UPC-29'' are attributed to the flexibility of L1 2-. The gradual replacement of the coordinated DMF molecules by H2O molecules indicates the hydrophilicity of the paddlewheel SBUs.

elements.content: Contact-angle measurements were taken to evaluate the hydrophobic/philic characteristics of UPC-29. For the loose-packed single-crystal state of UPC-29, the water contact angle was observed to be 178 ± 1°, suggesting its poor wettability for a small amount of water (a). However, in the state of the tight-pressed pellet with 10 MPa compressive force, the water contact angle was measured to be 118 ± 1° (b). In both states, the water contact angles are greater than 90°, which means the difficulty for water to reach the hydrophilic SBU, showing a hydrophobic property. Moreover, the contact angle of water is larger in the loose-packed form; this phenomenon can be attributed to the significantly distinct level of surface roughness. According to the Wenzel equation, decreasing the level of microscaled roughness via the application of pressure is unfavorable to the property of hydrophobicity. Therefore, under the synergy of surface energy and elastic potential energy, the contact angle of water is larger. In order to further prove the wettability of UPC-29, samples of UPC-29 were added to the vial with water, and they can float on water for 15 days without collapse (c). Surprisingly, samples of UPC-29 can sink in water after oscillating. This phenomenon further proves that UPC-29 possesses amphipathic characteristics (d).

However, in the state of the tight-pressed pellet with 10 MPa compressive force, the water contact angle was measured to be 118 ± 1° (b). In both states, the water contact angles are greater than 90°, which means the difficulty for water to reach the hydrophilic SBU, showing a hydrophobic property. Moreover, the contact angle of water is larger in the loose-packed form; this phenomenon can be attributed to the significantly distinct level of surface roughness. According to the Wenzel equation, decreasing the level of microscaled roughness via the application of pressure is unfavorable to the property of hydrophobicity. Therefore, under the synergy of surface energy and elastic potential energy, the contact angle of water is larger. In order to further prove the wettability of UPC-29, samples of UPC-29 were added to the vial with water, and they can float on water for 15 days without collapse (c). Surprisingly, samples of UPC-29 can sink in water after oscillating. This phenomenon further proves that UPC-29 possesses amphipathic characteristics (d).

elements.content: (a) Image of water (left) and oil (right) droplets on the surface of loose-packed crystals with a water contact angle of 178 ± 1°. (b) Image of a water droplet on the surface of pressed crystals with a water contact angle of 118 ± 1°. (c) Image of UPC-29 floating on the water surface. (d) Image of UPC-29 sinking in the water after oscillating. The inset figures indicate the static water contact angle.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Image of water (left) and oil (right) droplets on the surface of loose-packed crystals with a water contact angle of 178 ± 1°. (b) Image of a water droplet on the surface of pressed crystals with a water contact angle of 118 ± 1°. (c) Image of UPC-29 floating on the water surface. (d) Image of UPC-29 sinking in the water after oscillating. The inset figures indicate the static water contact angle.

elements.content: The water-vapor adsorption isotherm of UPC-29 was measured at 298 K. As depicted in Figure S13, UPC-29 exhibits a type V water sorption isotherm, categorized as a hydrophobic or weakly hydrophilic material, which reveals that UPC-29 adsorbs a small amount of water at P/P 0 < 0.6 until the sorption capacity increases suddenly. This phenomenon can be attributed to the increasing interaction between water and hydrophilic Cu-SBU units with an increase of pressure. The highest water-vapor uptake was 114 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.9, which is much lower than those of HKUST-1 and PDMS-coated HKUST-1, especially at low P/P 0, revealing the lower affinity of water to the hydrophobic surface of UPC-29. In addition, the water sorption kinetics of UPC-29 was significantly lower than that of HKUST-1. The water sorption experiment for UPC-29 takes about 40 h, while HKUST-1 can be finished in 24 h. The differences in the sorption kinetics between UPC-29 and HKUST-1 may be attributed to the introduction of the hydrophobic ligand, which resists the penetration of H2O molecules.
elements.clean_text: The water-vapor adsorption isotherm of UPC-29 was measured at 298 K. As depicted in Figure S13, UPC-29 exhibits a type V water sorption isotherm, categorized as a hydrophobic or weakly hydrophilic material, which reveals that UPC-29 adsorbs a small amount of water at P/P 0 < 0.6 until the sorption capacity increases suddenly. This phenomenon can be attributed to the increasing interaction between water and hydrophilic Cu-SBU units with an increase of pressure. The highest water-vapor uptake was 114 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.9, which is much lower than those of HKUST-1 and PDMS-coated HKUST-1, especially at low P/P 0, revealing the lower affinity of water to the hydrophobic surface of UPC-29. In addition, the water sorption kinetics of UPC-29 was significantly lower than that of HKUST-1. The water sorption experiment for UPC-29 takes about 40 h, while HKUST-1 can be finished in 24 h. The differences in the sorption kinetics between UPC-29 and HKUST-1 may be attributed to the introduction of the hydrophobic ligand, which resists the penetration of H2O molecules.

elements.content: Considering the special amphipathicity of UPC-29, we explored the separation ability for oil/water via a series of practical oil/water separation measurements. Part a and b of , S14, and S15 show the separation of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water with UPC-29 in the loose-packed form. Surprisingly, the colored water can pass through the crystal samples and drop into the vial beneath it, whereas no visible naphtha, gasoline, or diesel was observed to penetrate the crystal samples and still resided on the samples. Then we replaced the straight pipe filter with a U-tube filter. As expected, the colored water permeated through the crystals and flowed into the left side when the mixture of water and oil was poured directly into the right side of the U-tube filter. Moreover, the colored water could be returned to the right side of the U-tube filter if we tilted the U-tube filter to the right side. When we put the U-tube filter horizontally, the oil/water could be separated again and the oil could not be permeated through the crystals even when we tilted the U-tube filter to the left side (Figure S16). However, when moderate amounts of crystal samples were pressed with 10 MPa compressive force and fixed in the middle of the glass tube, an opposite result for oil/water separation was observed. While a mixture of water and oil was injected into the simple filter as we did in the previous experiments, the oil was absorbed and passed through the tight-pressed samples but the colored water was repelled and resided on the closed sample (parts c and d of , S14, and S15). Thus, this phenomenon indicates that UPC-29 can efficiently separate the oil/water mixture.
elements.clean_text: Considering the special amphipathicity of UPC-29, we explored the separation ability for oil/water via a series of practical oil/water separation measurements. Part a and b of , S14, and S15 show the separation of naphtha/water, gasoline/water, and diesel/water with UPC-29 in the loose-packed form. Surprisingly, the colored water can pass through the crystal samples and drop into the vial beneath it, whereas no visible naphtha, gasoline, or diesel was observed to penetrate the crystal samples and still resided on the samples. Then we replaced the straight pipe filter with a U-tube filter. As expected, the colored water permeated through the crystals and flowed into the left side when the mixture of water and oil was poured directly into the right side of the U-tube filter. Moreover, the colored water could be returned to the right side of the U-tube filter if we tilted the U-tube filter to the right side. When we put the U-tube filter horizontally, the oil/water could be separated again and the oil could not be permeated through the crystals even when we tilted the U-tube filter to the left side (Figure S16). However, when moderate amounts of crystal samples were pressed with 10 MPa compressive force and fixed in the middle of the glass tube, an opposite result for oil/water separation was observed. While a mixture of water and oil was injected into the simple filter as we did in the previous experiments, the oil was absorbed and passed through the tight-pressed samples but the colored water was repelled and resided on the closed sample (parts c and d of , S14, and S15). Thus, this phenomenon indicates that UPC-29 can efficiently separate the oil/water mixture.

elements.content: Photographs of diesel/water separation experiments: initial (a) and final (b) states of the separation experiments in the loose-packed form and initial (c) and final (d) states of the separation experiments in the tight-pressed form (water was dyed by acid red 18 for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 3  Photographs of diesel/water separation experiments: initial (a) and final (b) states of the separation experiments in the loose-packed form and initial (c) and final (d) states of the separation experiments in the tight-pressed form (water was dyed by acid red 18 for clarity).

elements.content: To further evaluate the separation efficiency, the oil rejection coefficient [R (%)] was calculated using the equation R ⁡ ( % ) = ( 1 − C s C o ) × 100 where C o and C s are the oil content in the original oil/water mixtures and the collected water after separation, respectively. According to the calculation, the separation efficiency for all of the tested objects is above 99.0%, as shown in a. We also tested the cycle performance of UPC-29; taking the naphtha/water separation as an example, the separation efficiency remained up to 99.4% after 8 cycles (b). Within the scope of the study, the as-prepared UPC-29 exhibited an excellent separation performance for oil/water. Furthermore, the oil/water separation can be explained as follows: UPC-29 has amphipathic characteristics, with Cu-SBU as the hydrophilic group and a pentiptycene-based unit as the hydrophobic group. When the samples of UPC-29 in the loose-packed form for the oil/water separation, the hydrophilic group of Cu-SBU plays the major role. After the oil/water mixture is added, the water is easily accessed to Cu-SBU under the action of pressure, and therefore the water can pass through the crystal samples. While the samples of UPC-29 in the tight-pressed form for the oil/water separation, the pentiptycene-based units take advantage of the hydrophobicity as a result of the difficulty for water to contact with Cu-SBU. Therefore, the oil can pass through the samples and more and more water is repelled. Thus, the interesting results indicate that UPC-29 can be a highly promising candidate as an amphipathic material for oil/water separation.
elements.clean_text: To further evaluate the separation efficiency, the oil rejection coefficient [R (%)] was calculated using the equation     R ⁡  ( % )  =  ( 1 -     C   s       C   o     )  × 100    where C o and C s are the oil content in the original oil/water mixtures and the collected water after separation, respectively. According to the calculation, the separation efficiency for all of the tested objects is above 99.0%, as shown in a. We also tested the cycle performance of UPC-29; taking the naphtha/water separation as an example, the separation efficiency remained up to 99.4% after 8 cycles (b). Within the scope of the study, the as-prepared UPC-29 exhibited an excellent separation performance for oil/water. Furthermore, the oil/water separation can be explained as follows: UPC-29 has amphipathic characteristics, with Cu-SBU as the hydrophilic group and a pentiptycene-based unit as the hydrophobic group. When the samples of UPC-29 in the loose-packed form for the oil/water separation, the hydrophilic group of Cu-SBU plays the major role. After the oil/water mixture is added, the water is easily accessed to Cu-SBU under the action of pressure, and therefore the water can pass through the crystal samples. While the samples of UPC-29 in the tight-pressed form for the oil/water separation, the pentiptycene-based units take advantage of the hydrophobicity as a result of the difficulty for water to contact with Cu-SBU. Therefore, the oil can pass through the samples and more and more water is repelled. Thus, the interesting results indicate that UPC-29 can be a highly promising candidate as an amphipathic material for oil/water separation.

elements.content: (a) Oil/water separation efficiency for UPC-29 in different forms. (b) Naphtha/water separation cycle performance of UPC-29.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Oil/water separation efficiency for UPC-29 in different forms. (b) Naphtha/water separation cycle performance of UPC-29.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully fabricated and characterized a Cu-MOF (UPC-29) based on a flexible pentiptycene-based ligand. Significantly, UPC-29 contains hydrophilic Cu-SBU units and hydrophobic pentiptycene-based units. UPC-29 in this work can be realized through the efficient separation of oil/water, which further opens a new research area for the application of amphiphilic MOF materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully fabricated and characterized a Cu-MOF (UPC-29) based on a flexible pentiptycene-based ligand. Significantly, UPC-29 contains hydrophilic Cu-SBU units and hydrophobic pentiptycene-based units. UPC-29 in this work can be realized through the efficient separation of oil/water, which further opens a new research area for the application of amphiphilic MOF materials.

metadata.title:
Amphipathic Pentiptycene-Based Water-Resistant Cu-MOF
for Efficient Oil/Water Separation
